title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2011)
subject: Personal Development

document.title: Secondary – Cycle 1 – Progression of Learning - Ethics and Religious Culture (2011)

9C8D31E93ED84E8F89616D67E6C7ECC8.description: a conspiracy (e.g. “Can you prove that the politicians agreed on this point?”)

DEA9C7F326F64097BA0FEBE07FB1F5F7.description: a slippery slope (e.g. “Aren’t you exaggerating a little? Being late for this class will not determine the rest of my life.”)

752C7B6505104977875746ACB8069D6B.description: a false analogy (e.g. “Are the same skills required to sing and to play the guitar?”)

8AF2EC0F61184E82A45AD121FFEE4664.description: a causal fallacy (e.g. “Do all players who score goals use sticks autographed by their idols?”)

82E06CE8CD8C427B80B70083416D9948.description: a false dilemma (e.g. “What is the connection between getting your driver’s license and doing housework?”)

1AFE24CF48EC439BABFFD0AA733C64EC.description: a straw man argument (e.g. “What would we do in the middle of winter?”)

D55F63BE6D264AAC9A8A100570BD5563.description: “two wrongs don’t make a right” argument (e.g. “If your friend goes home at 7:00 p.m., should you do likewise?”)

1B5648C0D5AC4EFF9E021A6D399A5193.description: an argument from authority (e.g. “Regardless of what the sociologist said and regardless of his reputation, what do you think and what are your arguments?”)

83B1C524555542CC868D51BCE51A197F.description: an appeal to stereotype (e.g. “What is your basis for saying that boys are less co-dependent than girls?”)

B328F61B2B6146EC86A7C5B2268E8607.description: an appeal to prejudice (e.g. “Can you give me your definition of autonomy?”)

4AB46532C577469EB96860F4A25C7918.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. “Does the number of computers sold guarantee the quality of the model?”)

FED1B8028B974B00BD7F21E6687582AE.description: an appeal to the crowd (e.g. “Is everything your friends say always true?”)

EA346EB28B574F4094630FD5416A109B.description: a personal attack (e.g. “Do you really think that insulting me will help us find the solution?”)

60BE1FD0C45B4F90B78389ACADE7934B.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. “What is your basis for saying that all adolescents disobey their parents?”)

96E0D07680FC4D0DAC771E1121CCF411.description: Questions, in a situation involving dialogue:

83B4A480663A41E58346CE3647D8E24B.description: a conspiracy (e.g. “We will never be able to save the planet because politicians in all the rich countries have agreed that the economy is their priority.”)

34069F4E478244C2B354B85766EDE5B2.description: a slippery slope (e.g. “If you are late for class one more time, you will fail your exam, you won’t get your high school diploma and you will never find a job.”)

7A8E1183DA0C426BB51C62CD6BE0FADB.description: a false analogy (e.g. “Since that student plays the guitar so well, he or she must sing well.”)

EDDC0314EFF84121BBBBDBC0BA299725.description: a causal fallacy (e.g. “I scored a goal because I was playing with a hockey stick signed by my idol.”)

A03A357B264B4C7EAC50FB2717164C96.description: a false dilemma (e.g. “Either you let me get my driver’s license or I won’t do any more housework.”)

3682DA10A3294CD2BA23DA4F2973F457.description: a straw man argument (e.g. “Ecologists think that we should all wear green plants in order to save the planet.”)

C3370554B75D4657A4455D0E4BF476AB.description: “two wrongs don’t make a right” argument (e.g. “You came home much too late last night.” “But Dad, my friend Sam went home two hours later than I did!”)

A63DA994334B4B30B3BAFA2BB19DBE8D.description: an argument from authority (e.g. “I believe there is life after death because a famous sociologist said so.”)

085697BCAE8B4B998B60E2DBB868D845.description: an appeal to stereotype (e.g. “Boys are less co-dependent than girls.”)

F3DF9D7C8BB64BA0BAC9DEFA35AC387C.description: an appeal to prejudice (e.g. “A handicapped person can never be autonomous.”)

B4A427FB592D409983C84A8D7A736F30.description: an appeal to the crowd (e.g. “This computer has the highest sales; that means it must be the best model.”)

E9877CB6A29646A3A75A26A6DCD32D22.description: an appeal to the people (e.g. “My friends all say that the best form of justice is fairness, so it must be true.”)

C1B63FA3D27441D3B6FB500BFA109D0F.description: a personal attack (e.g. “You are not smart enough to find the solution.”)

AFBC57E1816F4366AA51A7402EA7FF61.description: a hasty generalization (e.g. “All adolescents disobey their parents.”)

E8BD1D67E1FB4EB6B6B83605F0FD64CA.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

28168A3E5A964E38B7A5B53EAE5FDD1B.description: “two wrongs don’t make a right” argument, a straw man argument, a false dilemma, a causal fallacy, a false analogy, a slippery slope, a conspiracy

576D7516EB744F4187139122366E4EC4.description: a hasty generalization, a personal attack, an appeal to the people, an appeal to the crowd (bandwagon), an appeal to prejudice, an appeal to stereotype, an argument from authority

D839C3CE9A9940C0898C26305C6A24BE.description: a judgment of value (e.g. “How is the social order more important to you than freedom?”)

CE54D810ACD443A69D4F18463146AF15.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. “Can you give an example of a story that has inspired the creation of a rite?”)

FE872E7D89C84BD0A156D68BD36A9E74.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. “Do I have to respect someone else’s freedom even if it limits my freedom?”)

23DBFDA1DB6C446B9B406301F0D061DC.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. “How are your parents’ norms better than those imposed by your friends’ parents?”)

2C8615E0FE59479EBCFD13A515D32527.description: Questions, in a situation involving dialogue:

057F9C9DB2984ACD9D6C022B67A635FE.description: a judgment of value (e.g. “The social order is more important than freedom.”)

A7E0FE81CF32483F91C8F68CE7FA4631.description: a judgment of reality (e.g. “The Bible tells a number of stories that have inspired the creation of religious rites.”)

05D5D6AC6FAF4C1D922A48E6C253720D.description: a judgment of prescription (e.g. “It’s important to respect the freedom of others.”)

8F845A6C77D34F9BA59C9619C15BCA4C.description: a judgment of preference (e.g. “I prefer the norms imposed by my parents to those imposed by my friends’ parents.”)

D15201F43A7C4CCEA559946497DB61FC.description: Recognizes, in a situation involving dialogue:

921C3CFDE1364E56B88624CC7B0D8DEB.description: Explains, in his/her own words the meaning of a judgment of preference, a judgment of prescription, a judgment of reality and a judgment of value

C9F6EDF1923045EA99A6557B21721E1D.description: Means for examining a point of view

3DDA88E57F724574899496E22F1E3B0A.description: Uses justification to present, in a logical way, a few reasons and ideas that support a point of view (e.g. in Cycle One, “I think everyone’s freedom is limited because there are rules, codes of conduct and laws that govern our behaviour;” in Cycle Two, “I believe that a pilgrimage is a religious experience, because the believer finds a spiritual meaning there and becomes personally involved, which strengthens his or her faith.”)

2D3473E398674BC3952DBD4DA67EE69F.description: Uses explanation to help others to know or understand the meaning of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, social order is an agreement between the members of a group about norms to be respected and values to be espoused; in Cycle Two, human ambivalence is a state in which a person is undecided about two options as they both involve equally important values)

F65B256253B441CAB7F6B572CF897F17.description: Uses synthesis to provide a coherent summary of the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, summarizes what he/she has learned about connections between the stories, rites and rules of religious traditions; in Cycle Two, summarizes his/her understanding of the different answers religious traditions propose for an existential question)

612BB5A80ACF4AD48069EFA74E1E7CF1.description: Uses comparison to highlight similarities and differences among the elements of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, names two differences between an adolescent and an adult’s conception of freedom; in Cycle Two, indicates the similarities and differences between Hubert Reeves and David Suzuki’s vision of the future of humanity)

7CF443AB49CF459EAB096ECC0853D812.description: Uses description to enumerate the characteristics of the subject discussed (e.g. in Cycle One, in the context of a story, describes the setting where the action takes place, the characters and the important events; in Cycle Two, in the context of a religious experience, describes the place where the experience took place, what the person felt, what actions were taken, what words were spoken, etc.)

9C8288C4460F4C588ACC222D93C25D7D.description: Explains, in his/her own words, the use of description, comparison, synthesis, explanation and justification

654DDA04B28947E5BA0BAC70A1FAF86C.description: Means for developing a point of view

FF17B79F273E412CAD2F6954B9D92507.description: considers all other paths for fostering dialogue

27B321BB55F4442ABE8C44815262E31D.description: is open to different ways of thinking

4C7EF6F097B64C6AAE32261553335DAE.description: introduces nuances to his/her comments and recognizes the nuances introduced by others

F39FFDAF97CB4825A71463DCB177CBE3.description: suggests rules for engaging in dialogue

BF346E2576E84775898972CFF6B050D6.description: Contributes to establishing conditions that foster dialogue:

B380B3947914412BB166002340AA39AB.description: considers all other paths for fostering dialogue,

135760CC06614464978BC75C2410CEF9.description: attentively listens to what another person has to say in order to grasp the meaning

3134EDCA7A904D1EBAA11AB5424ABC16.description: respects the right of others to speak

928B747EB0D5430AAD9EF9810BD0AE82.description: observes rules for engaging in dialogue

FE41F127810D4AE0941CCC6C03FE2CF7.description: conversation, discussion, narration, deliberation, interview, debate

B17D67F962154E89ABA4CEDC2E84A3F4.description: Uses, in a situation involving dialogue

005513FA82044D2D83BD37279D7472DA.description: Explains, in his/her own words, the meaning of a panel

4698FC9057AA4E00B3EA1E644C47DEEA.description: Knowledge related to the pratice of dialogue: Competency 3 – Engages in dialogue

FF8B60BEB6DA438982B6D5FE9BCF188C.description: Makes connections between the theme Representations of the divine and of mythical and supernatural beings and the recognition of others

DF69BDA2DE2349AD96F04B55FFD716EB.description: Makes connections between the theme Representations of the divine and of mythical and supernatural beings and the pursuit of the common good

77D2543C101945C19FB13C869EF1EB46.description: Makes connections between the theme Representations of the divine and of mythical and supernatural beings and the themes Québec’s religious heritage or Key elements of religious traditions

E2411FC460094C5580F13DF2794A2561.description: Describes attributes of mythical or supernatural beings according to different cultures and religious traditions: physical characteristics, feelings, qualities, etc.

DBFB55A7E4894DDA9A0C2DB177115C8E.description: Names mythical and supernatural beings associated with different cultures and religious traditions (e.g. gods and goddesses, mythical animals, angels, devils, spirits)

4CA9DDC299824D6AB834C9BEB5D586A7.description: Names symbols associated with the divine: colours: white, orange elements: fire, water vegetation: lotus flower, olive branch, etc.

430751192845455FBCAE56E1EBFA4257.description: Describes attributes of the divine according to different traditions: qualifiers: good, merciful, creator, omnipresent, omnipotent physical characteristics: human form, animal form (Native spirituality), blue skin and many arms (Hinduism), etc.

25EF8F4A25BB4198808E4AC0265F0E56.description: Gives the name or names attributed to the divine in different religious traditions: Christianity: Trinity, Father, Son, Holy Spirit Judaism: Adonai, Lord Native spirituality: Great Spirit Islam: Allah, etc

5AA0DB18686E465394ABA6B7E7565CFC.description: Defines terms that can be related to the divine and to mythical or supernatural beings (e.g. divinity, mythology, goddess, demon, supernatural, spirit, angel)

16C0F19DA84D46B9B1ED057CABC4E295.description: Representations of the divine and of mythical and supernatural beings

C46BDDDD05EA4FB280A2B6B618ACB015.description: Makes connections between the theme Key elements of religious traditions and the recognition of others

84BC8F4460744E009E18A2ECA539932C.description: Makes connections between the theme Key elements of religious traditions and the pursuit of the common good

91595B3D5F6B431094C6D2210509F6F0.description: Makes connections between the theme Key elements of religious traditions and the themes Québec’s religious heritage or Representations of the divine and of mythical and supernatural beings

C180C72E8C704D62A568DA9171DBC829.description: Makes connections between the stories, rites and rules of a religious tradition (e.g. the celebration of the Eucharist [rite] originates from the passion of Jesus [story] and the Catholic church asks its followers to attend Sunday mass [rule]; the Jewish holiday Sukkot [rite] originates from the story of the exodus from Egypt and, for this holiday, Jews must build an outdoor dwelling [rule] and have a meal there)

EBE0EA17C0784381947B80D681512ED7.description: Makes connections between key elements of religious traditions and forms of religious expression in the environment (e.g. church bells [form of religious expression] announce Sunday services [rite])

662ED2D1B3504C4EBABF25E49780A5A2.description: Describes different rules in religious traditions: type of rule, origin, prohibitions, obligations, etc.

11E5784CD4C545E59C223A28955127EE.description: Describes different rites in religious traditions: type of rite, origin, characteristics, role, procedure, etc.

8E53C4B54E7F42448A220D7F7B5CB763.description: Describes different stories in religious traditions: type of story, origin, characteristics, role, etc

0D32BFD89F3F455B815699D56B2CD4D7.description: Makes connections between the theme Québec’s religious heritage and the recognition of others

280F4B32F57F4A98800412A51F9B02D7.description: Makes connections between the theme Québec’s religious heritage and the pursuit of the common good

A91567F4D41E422FB42D164B9BC9D283.description: Makes connections between the theme Québec’s religious heritage and the themes Key elements of religious traditions or Representations of the divine and of mythical and supernatural beings

453C1A56F2E84DFF8794DADDCB82DD58.description: Describes the influence of religious traditions on the folklore and works of art in Québec’s heritage (e.g. influence of Christianity in Québec literature)

C8DB64DA0CF547A6BFFE56808ADB2018.description: Describes the influence of religious traditions on the values and norms in Québec society (e.g. influence on moral behaviour and moral codes, habits and customs, prohibitions)

59D59741ABEC4862BB54861E078F5502.description: Describes the contribution of religious institutions to Québec society, particularly in health care and education (e.g. construction of schools and hospitals, personnel mainly composed of nuns and monks, establishment of programs of study)

C68074B6DB384C1DADEA60443A4113DF.description: Describes religious institutions that are part of Québec’s heritage: origin, purpose, roles and responsibilities of religious personnel, hierarchy, etc.

A7470924F9DC4716B52466BE7B68971A.description: Names religious institutions that are part of Québec’s heritage (e.g. Frères du Sacré-Cœur community, the Sœurs de la Charité community)

B4BBE38EAF74411CA64F301B78C9F24E.description: Associates elements of religious heritage in the environment with founders (e.g. Hôtel-Dieu Hospital and the Augustinian nuns, the Society of Saint Vincent de Paul and the Vincentians)

619D1C74B641473F8FA8026789191F87.description: Names founders or influential figures in Québec’s religious heritage (e.g. Marie Guyart, Mgr François de Laval, Gaspar Soiaga Kondiaronk, Henriette Odin-Feller)

1C749430BA774BCFBE73BC2688433F10.description: Defines terms that can be connected to religious heritage (e.g. heritage, religious heritage, institutions, folklore)

154A61BEB5334F09819DE8A3CB860403.description: Knowledge related to themes of religious culture: Competency 2 – Demonstrates an understanding of the phenomenon of religion

D626FBACCA6747279867032CEB4894D9.description: Makes connections between the social order and the recognition of others

F37579A8A221404089180F0366A00041.description: Makes connections between the social order and the pursuit of the common good

B27B60654EB24537A809540187634582.description: Makes connections between ethical reflection on the social order and ethical reflection on autonomy or freedom

3FEEC14C886F43649312BEF46D02538B.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on the social order (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

81532C4FCD314F96B667CCB661B25C19.description: Formulates ethical questions about the social order (e.g. What behaviour should be encouraged or avoided when faced with a law that is considered unfair?)

7AC468A270E247D592F64358644099A9.description: Shows how values can inspire a person or a group to question or uphold the social order and the law (e.g. in the name of justice, a people rises up against the authoritative regime in power; for health reasons, a group of students advocates strict enforcement of the no-smoking legislation)

82E4B86D898E4D7CA42A0E562F0C63E4.description: Names factors that could bring about a change in social values and norms (e.g. war, immigration, the media, science)

1E6D01EB7DC24104BA4BA385344F3C5D.description: Describes different forms of disobedience (e.g. crime [serious, voluntary offence against the law]; civil disobedience [passive resistance and refusal to obey a law that is deemed to be unfair])

C082DA54149C4AFFAF0A339D9D6FFD4A.description: Describes different forms of obedience (e.g. submission [agreeing to submit without protest]; conformity [adopting the same behaviour as the majority])

D54455F4BCF343A1AA40D6CCD933C859.description: Describes different forms of power in groups, institutions or organizations (e.g. authoritative power [imposition of will]; democratic power [taking into account the majority vote by electing representatives])

2F4C06BA36FA4054959219B56F29D635.description: Uses examples to show that the social order is based on the values and norms adopted by groups, institutions and organizations (e.g. in many families, the social order is based on the values of love and sharing, as well as on family rules; in a theatre company, the social order is based on the director’s instructions [norms] as well as on the values of rigour and perseverance)

DB9A0FCC1F26430585EF91DC645A08FA.description: Makes connections between autonomy and the recognition of others

A7AEEEDD161D4D98B9CFDF36C60137C3.description: Makes connections between autonomy and the pursuit of the common good

8658CAB095A8418B8B1F618793C7DB70.description: Makes connections between ethical reflection on autonomy and ethical reflection on freedom or the social order

AE1360F27C904F7185D4513350DBF053.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on autonomy (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

A9D87A01F50F41C2AA5A2447CCCD5AC4.description: Formulates ethical questions about autonomy (e.g. Is it possible to be entirely autonomous? Why or why not?)

38A65BA2E27149E18975B8BC23ED4A0B.description: Explains how exercising one’s autonomy can become a source of tension (e.g. after deciding to dress in a certain style, an adolescent may come into conflict with his or her parents)

573197D5B2CC44B8B4601A8C38635332.description: hows how friendship, love, academic success, consumption, thrill-seeking, etc., can lead to autonomy or to dependence (e.g. a young person gains self-confidence through friendships with her peers and decides to look for a summer job; a young person enjoys playing music so much that he cannot stop and neglects his responsibilities)

07D2B9AD7033431CBF6E4E9A9DC2EDD7.description: Names conditions that foster autonomy (e.g. critical judgment, good sense, moral responsibility, the ability to choose, authenticity, resourcefulness)

DF9A0E7498A14002B2059CE2231CF7C7.description: Gives examples of signs of dependence in individuals or groups (e.g. a person who cannot stop playing online games; modern society cannot function without electricity)

D2231AE24A1F458FB3C3DD0C0529FB0B.description: Gives different definitions of the word dependence (e.g. the inability to develop one’s potential without someone else’s help; the state of a person who cannot carry out daily tasks alone)

FBD66432D4A641678C0937E326AAC660.description: Gives examples of signs of autonomy in individuals or groups (e.g. a visually impaired person goes out alone with a guide dog; team members organize their own practice when their coach is absent)

886CBF849ABF4BA0A01AE2C1E4CC023E.description: Gives different definitions of autonomy (e.g. ability to live without anyone’s help; right to self-government)

8D184583045F4E068B2A70764C0686F1.description: Makes connections between freedom and the recognition of others

892D28A77E8F4C99AA34DED38F7B232B.description: Makes connections between freedom and the pursuit of the common good

4A287BF9B2AC4774962E98E4617E0992.description: Makes connections between ethical reflection on freedom and ethical reflection on autonomy or the social order

AEE81035F3FA41179B2CF76DBEEF0E25.description: Names references that support and enrich ethical reflection on freedom (e.g. charters, laws, regulations, individuals, media)

3FDAA229ACD1479581468D7A645D8FE5.description: Formulates ethical questions about freedom (e.g. How does freedom imply limits?)

37EBF44E31834E68A9402C79D5B5114A.description: Uses examples to show how responsibilities, rights and duties limit the exercise of freedom (e.g. the freedom to express an opinion in a student newspaper does not relieve the authors of the obligation to avoid damaging another person’s reputation)

FDF535253D174A849F94538FF2C6FFF6.description: Makes connections between the exercise of freedom in private and in public (e.g. one expresses love for one’s sweetheart differently in private and in public; e-mailing a personal photo to a friend does not authorize him/her to publish it on a social network)

B616D08A0BCE42059471704CF477D4D5.description: Explains what motivates a person’s choices (e.g. a young person gets up early to train because he/she wants to do well in a sport; a group organizes a neighbourhood composting system because it believes that small actions will ensure the future of the planet)

BB2469B0F63E4E57A320AF8DC72E71B2.description: Gives the motives behind individual or group choices in the exercise of freedom (e.g. desires, needs, convictions, values, age, education, norms and physical or social constraints)

5C90B98542D8424B9857A45F2B1BC10A.description: Describes different types of freedom (e.g. freedom to act [ability to act as one wishes]; freedom of expression [ability to express oneself without fear of reprisal]; freedom of association [ability to join others with a shared objective])

768C7EF392774854AE10D1F723D662E4.description: Gives different definitions of freedom (e.g. situation of a person who is not dependent on anyone or anything; ability to act without constraints)

DBC80A38A2A74F18ABAFBBE5E6E557EC.description: Knowledge related to ethics themes: Competency 1 - Reflects on ethical questions
